revisions.rev:
{{good article}} {{Infobox single | Name = I've Got Nothing | Cover = I've Got Nothing.JPG | Border = yes | Alt = A square divided in half diagonally, from bottom-left to top-right. The top-left half is divided into 55 smaller squares, each containing the face of a different teenager. The bottom-right half is plain white, with the words "I've got nothing" and "ChartJackers" written over it in a black font. | Artist = ''[[Chartjackers]]'' | Released = {{Start date|2009|11|09|df=y}} (worldwide) | Format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | Recorded = {{Start date|2009|10|07|df=y}}
[[University of Wales, Newport]] | Genre = [[Pop music|Pop]] | Length = {{Duration|m=2|s=50}} | Label = Swinging Mantis | Producer = Marc Dowding}} "'''I've Got Nothing'''" is a song released by the participants of the [[BBC Two]] documentary series ''[[Chartjackers]]'' and is credited as such. The track was produced by university student Marc Dowding and its music video was filmed by [[YouTube]] user [[Charlie McDonnell]]. It was released by the [[record label]] Swinging Mantis on 9 November 2009 exclusively through the [[iTunes Store]]. The single and its release were the end product of a ten-week campaign documented on ''Chartjackers'', which challenged the global [[online community]] to write, record and release a pop song that would make number one on the [[UK Singles Chart]]. The song was written entirely through [[crowdsourcing]], with its every aspect, such as the title, lyrics, melody and singers, having been solicited from YouTube users. "I've Got Nothing" was a [[Charity record|charity single]] released to benefit the UK charity [[Children in Need]]. It was sung by vocalists [[Miranda Chartrand]] and Adam Nichols, both on the record and at live performances. Its music video featured shots of Chartrand and Nichols singing in a [[London]] park with Children in Need mascot Pudsey Bear, as well as video clips submitted by ''Chartjackers'' viewers of themselves miming to the track. The song was generally ignored by music critics and received mostly negative reviewsâit went on to sell a total of 20,000 copies worldwide and earned a chart position of Number 36 in the [[UK Singles Chart]]. ==Background and writing== {{Main|Chartjackers}} "I've Got Nothing" was written in ten weeks entirely through crowdsourcing{{Cite web|url=http://www.hypebot.com/hypebot/2009/11/chartjackers-can-a-crowdsourced-song-top-uk-charts.html|title=Chartjackers: Crowdsourcing To Top The UK Charts|date=17 November 2009|publisher=Hypebot|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc2SqF77|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}}{{Cite news|title=Four YouTube legends, one mind-blowing challenge as Chartjackers comes to BBC Switch|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2009/09_september/08/chartjackers.shtml|publisher=[[BBC]]|location=[[London]]|date=8 September 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc2WlL88|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=13 November 2010}} as part of a project that was documented on the BBC Two series ''Chartjackers''. Members of the online community were asked to submit various song ideas on the YouTube channel "ChartJackersProject", with the aim that a single could be written, recorded and then released on 9 November 2009. The lyrics for "I've Got Nothing" were written on the week of 8 September. A video posted to the YouTube channel "ChartJackersProject" invited viewers to submit possible lines as comments.{{Cite web|title=Lyrics Week|publisher=[[Youtube]]|format=Flash video|date=8 September 2009|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xi0BfpBgrJw|accessdate=7 November 2010}} Viewers posted more than 4,000 comments,{{Cite news|title=Chesney Hawkes to play with Chartjackers|first=Mayer|last=Nissim|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a185051/chesney-hawkes-to-play-with-chartjackers.html|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|date=3 November 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc2fvY0I|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} from which the song's lyrics were selected and compiled by YouTube user "hexachordal". The following week, another video was uploaded to "ChartJackersProject" that published the winning lyrics and announced that the song's title was to be "I've Got Nothing"{{Cite web|title=Melodies Week|publisher=[[Youtube]]|format=Flash video|date=17 September 2009|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EEpQmaVRx8M|accessdate=7 November 2010}}âthe song's chorus had been written by YouTube user "blakeisno1". The video also invited viewers to compose a melody for the completed lyrics. Viewers submitted 51 melodies as video responses,{{Cite episode|title=Episode 2|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IAaLHQSkFcQ|series=[[Chartjackers]]|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC Two]]|airdate=19 September 2009|seriesno=1|number=2}} with the entry from Jonny Dark, a 19-year-old musician from London, being selected as the winner.{{Cite web|title=Auditions â We need a band.|format=Flash video|publisher=[[Youtube]]|date=25 September 2009|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NQI1tKSlrfM|accessdate=7 November 2010}} A new YouTube video was uploaded to "ChartJackersProject" on 25 September, offering viewers the opportunity to audition to sing "I've Got Nothing" on the final release. Hundred of viewers auditioned, with ten being selected to go through as finalists.{{Cite episode|title=Episode 4|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Me4tCJEUSUY|series=[[Chartjackers]]|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC Two]]|airdate=3 October 2009|seriesno=1|number=4}} These ten finalists auditioned in person at the Wellfield Working Men's Club in [[Rochdale]],{{Cite web|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/rochdaleobserver/news/s/1159508_club_comes_into_focus_for_new_tv_show|title=Club comes into focus for new TV show|date=7 October 2009|publisher=''[[Rochdale Observer]]''|location=[[Rochdale]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc2tu5SI|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} where Miranda Chartrand, a 19-year-old au pair from [[Stroud, Gloucestershire]], and Adam Nichols, an 18-year-old musician from [[Essex]], were chosen to perform "I've Got Nothing" on the single.{{Cite episode|title=Episode 5|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=37schWBihmA|series=[[Chartjackers]]|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC Two]]|airdate=10 October 2009|seriesno=1|number=5}} ==Recording and release== [[Image:Campus-snow.gif|thumb|alt=Photograph of the Caerleon Campus of the University of Wales, Newport.|"I've Got Nothing" was recorded at the [[University of Wales, Newport]].]] "I've Got Nothing" was produced and co-written by university student Marc Dowding. Dowding learnt about the opportunity through a video posted to the YouTube channel "ChartJackersProject"{{Cite web|title=Producer Search & Band Auditions!|format=Flash video||publisher=[[YouTube]]|date=22 September 2009|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iFjmzMH3lhg|accessdate=7 November 2010}} and was offered the job after e-mailing his [[Curriculum vitae|CV]] to a [[BBC Switch]] producer.{{Cite news|title=Chartjackersâ hit produced by Creative Newport Student|url=http://citypartners.newport.ac.uk/news/displayStory.aspx?story_id=432|publisher=[[University of Wales, Newport]]|location=[[Newport]]|date=23 October 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc30aKbm|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} Chartrand and Nichols travelled to [[Newport]], [[South Wales]] on 7 October to record the single at the recording studio of the [[University of Wales, Newport]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xxF4BmKDWfM|title=Official Update from 1/2 of the Voices of Chartjackers.. Miranda's newest UPDATE!|first=Miranda|last=Chartrand|authorlink=Miranda_Chartrand|date=12 October 2009|format=Flash video|publisher=[[YouTube]]|location=[[Stroud, Gloucestershire]]|accessdate=7 November 2010}} On producing the single, Dowding remarked: "It was a great help to be able to use the recording studios at the University." "I've Got Nothing" was leaked to the internet during October 2009, before being officially released a month later by record label Swinging Mantis.{{Cite web|title=The Official Chart with Reggie Yates, 15/11/2009|publisher=[[BBC Radio 1]]|location=[[London]]|date=15 November 2009|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00nvd1y|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc35ksrY|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} As Swinging Mantis was a small record label, the budget for "I've Got Nothing" was limited, so a physical version of the single was never made available. Instead, the track was made sold exclusively as an iTunes [[Music download|digital download]]. "I've Got Nothing" was released worldwide through the [[iTunes Store]] at midnight on 9 November.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pudsey/news/news061109b.shtml|title=Chartjackers attack the charts|month=November|year=2009|publisher=[[BBC]]|location=[[London]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc39T6CA|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} Each copy was sold for Â£0.79 in the United Kingdom{{Cite web|last=Bowers|first=Mary|title=YouTube if you want to be a star|date=13 November 2009|format=ECE|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article6914409.ece|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc3D0W3W|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} and $0.99 in the United States.{{Cite web|url=http://itunes.apple.com/us/album/ive-got-nothing-single/id336614737|title=I've Got Nothing â Single by ChartJackers|date=9 November 2009|publisher=[[iTunes]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc3FWRRe|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=1 January 2011}} ==Reception== ===Critical response=== {{Listen | filename = I'veGotNothing.oggâ | title = "I've Got Nothing" | description = "I've Got Nothing" featured sound clips of ''[[Chartjackers]]'' viewers singing and clapping along with the track. }} "I've Got Nothing" was largely ignored by the [[mainstream media]] and did not receive many reviewsâthe reviews that it did receive from critics were generally negative. British music website [[Popjustice]] called the effort "very bad",{{Cite news|title=Subtle hints that Simon Cowell might not always be musically motivated|url=http://www.popjustice.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4212|publisher=[[Popjustice]]|date=16 November 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc3PkIws|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} and Ellie Halfacre of Tower Review explained that "some commented that the melody was bad, and others said it was the lyrics".{{Cite web|last=Halfacre|first=Ellie|title=I've Got Nothing|publisher=Tower Review|date=19 January 2010|url=http://towerreview.wordpress.com/2010/01/19/ive-got-nothing/|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc3SboUZ|archivedate=17 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} Halfacre also questioned whether the project was about self-promotion or charity. David Balls of [[Digital Spy]] gave the single three stars out of five, predicting that it was "unlikely to make much of a top 40 impact".{{Cite web|title=Music â Single Reviews|last=Balls|first=David|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|date=9 November 2009|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/singlesreviews/a186401/chartjackers-ive-got-nothing.html|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc3XQ0UR|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} [[James Masterton]] of [[Yahoo! Music]] felt that the song had "fallen a long way short of" the goal of reaching number one because it had not been able to "guarantee mass public support".{{Cite web|last=Masterton|first=James|authorlink=James_Masterton|title=Chart Watch UK|date=16 November 2009|publisher=[[Yahoo! Music]]|url=http://new.uk.music.yahoo.com/blogs/chartwatch/5358/week-ending-november-21st-2009/|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc3Zlbmt|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} Record producer [[Mike Stock (musician)|Mike Stock]] said that the song had "no killer melody"{{Cite episode|title=Episode 3|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=071L0s_o5Mk|series=[[Chartjackers]]|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC Two]]|airdate=26 September 2009|seriesno=1|number=3|minutes=3:29}} and singer [[VV Brown]] suggested that "the lyrics could be better".{{Cite episode|title=Episode 3|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=071L0s_o5Mk|series=[[Chartjackers]]|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC Two]]|airdate=26 September 2009|seriesno=1|number=3|minutes=1:57}} ===Commercial performance=== Expectations for the release of "I've Got Nothing" were high. The main goal of ''Chartjackers'' had been for the song to reach number one on the [[UK Singles Chart]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pudsey/news/news090909.shtml|title=Chartjackers go for number one|month=September|year=2009|publisher=[[BBC]]|location=[[London]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc3ehHrP|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} with the synopsis of the first episode expecting it to "sell an estimated 25,000 singles".{{Cite web|title=Chartjackers, Episode 1|publisher=[[BBC Switch]]|location=[[London]]|date=12 September 2009|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00mwbfy|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc3iGHDP|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} The single sold almost 20,000 copies worldwide and raised Â£10,000 for the charity Children in Need.{{Cite episode|title=Compilation|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R5csWCO5STI|series=[[Chartjackers]]|credits=Producers: Jonathan Davenport and Adam King|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC Two]]|airdate=21 November 2009|seriesno=1|number=11}} Just under 8,400 copies were downloaded in the UK,{{Cite journal|magazine=[[Music Week]]|issue=21.11.09|location=[[London]]|publisher=[[United Business Media]]|issn=0265-1548|oclc=60620772|date=21 November 2009|editor-last=Williams|editor-first=Paul}} which gave "I've Got Nothing" a chart placing of Number 36 in the UK Singles Chart.{{Cite web|title=Singles Chart For 21/11/09|publisher=Chart Stats|date=16 November 2009|url=http://www.chartstats.com/chart.php?week=20091121|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc3rFHvM|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} The following week the single fell out of the UK Top 100.{{Cite web|title=Singles Chart For 28/11/09|date=23 November 2009|publisher=Chart Stats|url=http://www.chartstats.com/chart.php?week=20091128|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc3uJ1rY|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} ==Music video== [[Image:I've Got Nothing music video.PNG|250px|left|thumb|alt=A young girl, a person dressed as a large smiling, yellow teddy bear and a young man stand in a grassy park, with their hands over their hearts. Their mouths are open, as if singing. The girl is wearing a blue jacket and a yellow scarf. The man is wearing a checked shirt and a white T-shirt. The teddy bear outfit has a polka dot bandana stitched over the bear's right eye.|Chartrand (left) and Nichols with [[Children in Need]] mascot Pudsey Bear in the music video for "I've Got Nothing".]] The music video for "I've Got Nothing" was edited by YouTube user [[Charlie McDonnell]].{{Cite episode|title=Episode 7|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=baXD5a4-yHg|series=[[Chartjackers]]|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC Two]]|airdate=24 October 2009|seriesno=1|number=7}} It shows various "ChartJackersProject" viewers miming to the song, interspersed with shots of Chartrand and Nichols singing "I've Got Nothing" in a park. The video was created through [[crowdsourcing]], in a manner similar to the writing of the song itself. On 8 October 2009, viewers were invited via "ChartJackersProject" to film and submit video clips of themselves either singing or clapping along with the track.{{Cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E-sTPf0q8cQ|title=Sing-along and Clap-along|date=8 October 2009|format=Flash video|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=7 November 2010}} Shots of Chartrand and Nichols with an actor dressed as [[Children in Need]] mascot Pudsey Bear were filmed in a park. This footage was compiled with some of the clips submitted by viewers and used to construct the final music video, which was shown nationwide on British [[Music television|music channels]] such as [[4Music]] and [[Viva (UK & Ireland)|Viva]]. Many viewers submitted clips that were literal interpretations of the lyrics. For example, some viewers held up medals and trophies for the lyric "won the greatest prize", others zoomed-in on their own eye during the line "look into my eyes" and others turned off lights for the lyric "the lights are going out". Most of the shots of Chartrand and Nichols are of them singing "I've Got Nothing" in a park with an actor dressed as Pudsey Bear, but the video also features shots of them eating [[ice cream]], swinging around a lamp post and dancing in front of a tree. The video begins with shots of the duo throwing a [[Football (association football)|football]] back and forth to each other. At 2:03, the video splits into 35 equally sized smaller rectangles, each containing a clip of a "ChartJackersProject" viewer clapping in time with "I've Got Nothing". Over the next 18 seconds of the song, 11 different sets of 35 viewers (i.e. approximately 385 viewers in total) are shown clapping along with the song. The video also features a cameo from YouTube user [[Peter Oakley]] at 0:06.{{Cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hYDRWXjJlB4|title="I've Got Nothing" â ChartJackers Music Video|date=8 November 2009|format=Flash video|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=7 November 2010}} ==Live performances== [[Image:Chesney-Hawkes-200806240230.jpg|thumb|alt=Chesney Hawkes singing live at a gig.|Singer [[Chesney Hawkes]] headlined a gig where "I've Got Nothing" was performed.]] "I've Got Nothing" was first performed live by Chartrand and Nichols on 4 November 2009 at [[93 Feet East]] in [[London]]. Their performance was shown during the ninth episode of ''Chartjackers''.{{Cite episode|title=Episode 9|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sn6A-G9Istw|series=[[Chartjackers]]|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC Two]]|airdate=7 November 2009|seriesno=1|number=9}} The gig also featured performances from other YouTube users and was headlined by former pop star [[Chesney Hawkes]]. The song was performed live for a second time four days later at Switch Live 2009, an awards show organised by [[BBC Switch]] at the [[HMV Hammersmith Apollo]]âthe event was opened by a performance of "I've Got Nothing".{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/images/156109/|title=Go Chartjackers! And Tom Deacon. Obvs.|month=November|year=2009|publisher=[[BBC Switch]]|location=[[London]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wc3zsxHr|archivedate=19 February 2011|accessdate=7 November 2010}} ==Track listing== {{Track listing | headline = Digital download | title1 = I've Got Nothing | length1 = 2:50}} ==Charts== {|class="wikitable" |- !Chart (2009) !Peak
position |- {{Singlechart|UKchartstats|36|song=I've Got Nothing|songid=34637|artist=Chartjackers|accessdate=7 November 2010}} |} ==Credits and personnel== *[[Miranda Chartrand]] â vocals *Adam Nichols â vocals *Jonny Dark â writer (melody) *Marc Dowding â writer, [[Record producer|producer]], [[Audio engineer|engineer]] and [[Audio mixing (recorded music)|mixer]] ==See also== *[[2009 in British music]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.last.fm/music/Chartjackers/_/I've+Got+Nothing "I've Got Nothing"] at [[Last.fm]] *{{YouTube|id=hYDRWXjJlB4|title="I've Got Nothing" music video}} {{Chartjackers}} {{Good article}} {{Use British English|date=January 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}} [[Category:Chartjackers]] [[Category:British pop songs]] [[Category:Charity singles]] [[Category:Debut singles]] [[Category:2000s pop songs]] [[Category:2009 singles]]
